tweets.text:
OK, lets do this. One like = one tweet about emotions, especially the nature of emotions, maximum of one hundred tweets.

Topic suggested by a friend in private and I liked it. Fair warning: I'm still figuring all of this out myself.

1. OK, first of all, what the hell are emotions?

The theory that feels most useful to me is that emotions are words describing aspects of subjective experience. I tend to use "feelings" for the broader subjective experience. I'll talk about both emotions and feelings.

2. This doesn't mean emotions aren't real, just that they're necessarily simplifications of a much richer experience. They are the handles we use to try to understand that experience, and because we act on that understanding they tend to feed back and influence our feelings.

3. A good way of getting a handle on this distinction is Focusing, which is an introspection tool for understanding your feelings about the subject in fairly rich detail. I recommend the book. https://t.co/7J1O3Gfi3c

(It sounds much more cultish than it is)

4. The "How Emotions are Made" model suggests that the emotion words we use to make sense of our feelings heavily impacting those feelings. This seems plausible but maybe overly strong to me, but developing richer emotional vocabulary seems to be helpful

 https://t.co/HpUVbUOK9Y

5. Emotions are intimately connected with reasoning. People think they're opposed, but nothing could be further from the truth: People who are disconnected from their emotional processing make really bad decisions and are unable to prioritise.

6. A common problem is alexithymia, which is difficulty understanding and processing your own emotions. My suspicion is that most people with alexithymia actually just don't have the relevant skill set and that people who have those skills mostly lucked into them.

7. One of the easiest ways to fail to develop a skill set is to not want to. If most of your emotional experiences (especially in formative years) are unpleasant, you're rarely going to want to pay attention to your emotions, which would discourage you from learning to.

8. Unfortunately this also means that even if fixing alexithymia is "just" a matter of developing the skill set, as soon as you start working on it you're going to be hit with a whole pile of unpleasant feelings you've gotten really good at ignoring. This is... not a lot of fun.

9. I think people confuse regulating and suppressing feelings. Regulating feelings actually requires having more feelings, not less, because if you suppress them what will happen is they'll build up until you *can't* ignore them.

10. I still struggle with regulation of aversive emotions. There are a lot of things where I know that my reaction to something is negative, and I can often even trace why, but that doesn't really help me figure out what to do about it. Tips welcome.

11. A point made in Matthew Radcliffe's "Experiences of Depression" is that the nature of feelings (he uses the term slightly differently from me) is much richer than you might expect. He suggests two types: Intentional (about something) and existential (structuring the world).

12. For example hope is an intentional feeling (you are hoping *for* something), while hopelessness is an existential one (the world lacks even the possibility of hope). These existential feelings constrain what intentional feelings are even possible for you to have.

13. I often notice that our vocabulary for talking about this isn't very good in a specific way: We seem to use the same words for multiple things that are either subtly or wildly different. e.g. emotions can describe both behaviour and feelings, and these aren't the same thing.

14. What does it actually *mean* to say that someone is angry but doesn't realise it? If anger is an emotion and emotions are descriptions of one's own internal feelings, if they don't have access to those feelings are they "really" angry?

(I think "yes but it's complicated")

15. "Feelings" is another multiple meaning word. Both "I am experiencing a feeling of hopelessness" and "My heart is racing" describe feelings, but they're quite different sorts of feelings. OTOH there's a more or less continuous gradient between those two kinds of feeling.

16. I don't necessarily want to commit to this but I think it might be useful to use "sensations" as a distinguishing word for feeling. e.g. "My heart is racing" is a sensation which might lead to the feeling "I need to escape", which you could describe as "being anxious".

17. There isn't necessarily a hard and fast line as to what is a sensation, what is a feeling, and what is an emotion. There's continuity between all three. It's more of a question of which aspect of the experience you're focusing (or Focusing!) on.

18. I think people often think that the sensations you experience are side effects of the emotion. The causality actually goes:

1. My heart is racing.
2. Therefore I feel like I need to escape.
3. Therefore I feel anxious.

But people assume it's the opposite.

19. This realisation that emotions are fundamentally embodied seems to be missing from popular conceptions of emotions. It's a normal concept in therapeutic contexts, but outside those circles people tend to think emotions are in their head and just happen to affect their body.

20. None of which is to say that your brain isn't involved in your emotions - of course it is - but there's a complex brain/body feedback loop.

Brain: Uh oh. This looks like bad thing. Better prepare.
Body: *enters flight or fight mode* <- sensation that starts the emotion loop.

21. Circling back to regulation vs suppression: I think a lot of where everybody gets fucked up is that kids have a lot of feelings (the world is pretty overwhelming when everything is new!) and it's much easier to teach them to suppress those than to regulate them.

22. My impression is that which version of the bad lessons in what to do about emotions you get depends on which gender you're assigned (and also culture). In broad strokes, boys get taught to ignore their emotions, while girls get taught to second guess theirs. Both are bad.

23. The difference being whether you are aware of your emotional experience or not - not noticing you feel X vs noticing that you feel X and deciding that that's stupid and you shouldn't feel X. I think the former is worse for you, but that might be a grass is greener thing.

24. Regardless of whether it's worse, you tend to have to pass through the latter stage in fixing it. If you've been ignoring your emotional state it's probably a mess, so when you stop ignoring it you're not going to like it much.

25. "Your feelings are valid" is a route out of the second guessing stage - it stops you from going "But I SHOULDN'T feel this way" and helps you approach those feelings with curiousity. But it's a strategy more than a truth. Feelings aren't valid, or invalid, they just are.

26. Saying "It's valid to feel hurt" is no more or less true than "It's valid to have a broken leg". It doesn't really matter whether it's valid or not, your leg is still broken. The question is what to do about it, and maybe prioritise the leg over self-recrimination.

27. As a strategy rather than a truth, you can take or leave it depending on whether it's currently working for you. Sometimes it's better to go "No, these emotions are bullshit, I'm just going to weather them until I'm in a healthier place for dealing with it."
(I'm going to pause for a bit. Will resume later)

28. The less pithy but I think more important version of "your feelings are valid" is I think this: Feelings are not moral failings. You don't have to like or dislike how you feel, but feelings do not reflect badly on you, only your actions on those feelings.

29. Lets get personal for a minute. My particular emotional processing problem I'm working on at the moment is this: I'm actually very good at emotional awareness... as long as I pay attention. And I really don't want to pay attention. It's at best too intense, at worse aversive.

30. I wouldn't exactly say I have alexithymia. Given the level of introspective discussions about emotions I have with friends I suspect some people I know would smack me if I said I had it. But it's definitely something in that general space.

31. This enables a level of self-analysis that I imagine looks quite impressive from the outside, but it's kinda weird only having awareness of emotional states through conscious introspection.

I think it's less weird and more normal than it sounds, but it's still weird.

32. My suspicion is that it's partly a disocciation thing, and that a lot of people (especially men) are disocciating a lot more than we credit, and that a lot of failures of emotional processing are actually dissociative states where your mind is disconnecting from your body.

33. Dissociation is of course not male-specific, but given that a) Emotions are experienced bodily and b) Boys are trained to ignore their emotions and "toughen up", the easiest way to do that is to learn to dissociate, and I think most of us start doing it quite young.

(I expect much of that will apply equally to trans people who were forced through masculinity training despite not being male. I'm not going to talk that much about that side of things because it would be theorising well outside my experience)
34. The big problem with ignoring your feelings is that they don't actually stop working - they still do exactly what they're designed to do, that information is just screened off from you.

35. You know the "Not sure if the world is terrible and everyone hates me or if I need to eat a sandwich" problem? That is what *everything* is like if you're not paying attention to how you're feeling. Your behaviour will not make sense to you.

36. The claims I've read for the damage suppressed emotions do to your physical health and how much healthy emotional processing helps are so dramatic that frankly I don't believe them, but I'd be surprised if there wasn't at least some link between emotions and physical health.

37. In particular constant muscle tension is bad for you, and if you suppress awareness of how stressed you are then you're going to be in a permanent fight or flight state that keeps your body tense.

(I suspect this is my problem - I genuinely don't know how to relax muscles)

38. Clarification of https://t.co/ylS4JUmrmc

They do what they're designed to do but you don't act on that. e.g. a body in fight or flight is fine if you're going to fight or flee. It's a terrible idea if you're going to sit there pretending things are fine.

39. Have you noticed that people often outsource their emotions to those around them? Especially positive ones. e.g. I've pointed out before that the manic pixie dream girl is a fantasy of vicariously experiencing joy. https://t.co/JBkaF5IEEX

40. I am not entirely sure how this fits in with the emotions as expressions of bodily feelings model. It seems like it doesn't. It's closer to a form of empathy, which is a kind of second-person subjective experience. You're experiencing emotions from *someone else's* feelings.

41. There is definitely something about emotions which is shared though - this ties in to the "emotions as behaviour vs emotions as feelings" thing. e.g. it seems to make sense to talk about the mood of a crowd, and that it's more than the sum of the mood of its members

42. Your experience of emotions through others doesn't actually come from their feelings though. Consider watching a sad movie. The loop goes:

Their behaviour -> Your feelings -> Your emotions

You're modelling this as if their feelings were involved but they're not really.

43. In a normal group emotional experience there are many feedback loops that do extend through everyone's feelings. e.g. in a conversation there's a loop my feelings -> my behaviour -> your thoughts -> your feelings -> your behaviour -> my thoughts -> my feelings.

44. One of the most obvious benefits I've found to improving emotional processing is that it's often essential to getting unblocked - when there's something I can't make myself do, being able to understand why is often key to doing it.
45. I suspect this is only the most obvious benefit because I'm not making especially good progress and this is the low hanging fruit.

46. Also just because I can do this doesn't actually mean I'm magically never blocked. I've got several big things I've been blocked on for months, partly because even the question of identifying why I'm blocked on them is aversive.

47. I mentioned briefly Matthew Ratcliffe's notion of "Existential Feelings" as feelings which structure your current subjective experience. One important such structuring is that often depression is experienced as a restriction on what emotions you can currently feel.

48. In "emotional blunting" this can be total and you feel emotionless, but even without that depression is often experienced as the feeling that some feelings are impossible. I mentioned hopelessness, but also joylessness: Not just a lack of joy, but that joy is impossible.

49. One thing that can be helpful is to notice that not all positive emotions go away. e.g. I often find that I am capable of sustaining interest in things (experiencing the feeling of interest) during depressive episodes where I'm not really capable of other positives.

50. An odd way this shows up for me is what games I'm able to play. For example I cannot play Untitled Goose Game while depressed, because playing it relies on being able to experience the emotion of "glee" fairly heavily - there's really not much game there if you can't.

51. Celeste on the other hand I can play even while fairly depressed, because the emotions it requires are mostly interest, stubbornness, and rage, which tend to be ones I have relatively stable access to.

(read what you will into how much Celeste I've been playing recently)

52. The Goose game example is interesting, because nobody would say they feel "gleeless", but the feeling is quite specific and is different from joylessness. My suspicion is that experiencing restricted emotional ranges is quite common but we don't notice most of them.

53. There seems to be a huge amount of variation in the intensity with which people experience emotions, and I cannot tell how much of this is healthy variation and how much of it is that disassociation and some forms of depression tend to dial down the intensity.

54. Also some forms of depression dial up the intensity. I can't say much of that from personal experience (or much about intense emotional experiences at all - I am very much on the not intense end of the scale, and a lot of my current work is on trying to understand that)

55. An idea that is common in some of my circles is that basically everyone is traumatised to some greater or lesser degree, and that trauma is the root of most of our emotional regulation problems. This seems... more plausible to me than it used to, but I have many questions.

56. The everything-is-trauma model people seem to be like everyone else in that it promises a miracle fix and that everything can be easily cured with this one weird trick. I think they're probably mostly right, but I'm not yet convinced they're right in a helpful way.

57. I think it probably *is* the case that school, family, and other bad childhood experiences have left most of us carrying around a lot of anxiety that we don't really understand and are suppressing most of the time, and that most people would benefit from untangling that.

58. My own unsubstantiated theory: experiencing a range of emotions under controlled and comprehensible circumstances is one of the biggest benefits of therapy and other things, because it serves as a kind of "emotional callisthenics" that helps you learn to expand your range.

59. I suspect this is also part of why some types of drug use are helpful for depression - they get you into pleasant and interesting mental states and let you hang out in those states for a while, and knowing what that feels like helps those states feel possible.

(Side note: My own experience of therapy is minimal. I didn't find it that helpful and haven't been willing to put in the time and money to find a therapist who I gelled with, but I read a lot of therapy books and there's a lot of therapy knowledge ambient in my social group)

60. A lot of unpleasant/aversive emotions, especially anxiety, are the continuation of operant conditioning by other means: If you get punished for a thing, that thing will acquire negative associations, and eventually that replaces the need for punishment.

61. I have been utterly failing to read "unlocking the emotional brain" (good summary: https://t.co/BiLsuDUg3z) but it suggests that these learned aversions can be overcome by essentially activating them, learning a replacement, and integrating the two. Plausibility level: Maybe.
(I'm going to take a break for the night and resume this thread tomorrow)

62. Bonus night tweet: A problem with the "emotions as words describing our feelings" model is that it misses some cases where it feels natural to use emotion words. For example it sure seems valid to say that this cat is very sad that she's not being allowed into my bedroom.

63. Joking aside, the question of whether animals have emotions is an important one. They have sensations and feelings but not language. I think maybe this is a category error - nothing *has* emotions, they just have things that we can usefully describe as emotional.

64. The "How Emotions are Made" model suggests that our conception of our emotions is a major part of generating feelings. Animals without language seem to exhibit a relatively rich range of emotional behaviour without that feedback though, so it's worth observing the difference.

65. This kinda points to a big problem underlying this thread: There are lots of plausible seeming theories about how all of this works and all of them have holes in them. I lack the expertise to really judge, and the experts very much haven't formed consensus yet.

66. In "Focusing-Oriented Psychotherapy", Gendlin suggests that the  benchmark of therapeutic theories is what experiences they unlock. I think something like this is also true here: Emotional theories are almost all oversimplifications, but can help work on emotional range.

67. e.g. I don't know if the theory of constructed emotions is true, but treating it as true is often useful for considering one feedback loop in the mind-body-society ecosystem, and to the degree that it helps one find fine-grained emotional language it can only be helpful.

68. Emotions are Biopsychosocial, a word that means "This shit's complicated, y'all" - they involve a complex interplay between three things already too complicated to fully understand (biology, psychology, sociology). Theories are mostly taking a thin slice through that mess.

69. This is not bad. Thin slicing is exactly what we need in order to reason about emotions. It's more a commentary on the expected range of validity of theories: We should hold them lightly, and let them suggest actions, but not be too surprised when those actions don't work.

(Aside: We've now hit the 100-tweet limit on number of likes. You can keep liking the original tweet if you, err, like, but it won't increase the number of tweets about emotions. I'll get to 100 and then maybe do a wrap up tweet or two)

70. Another interesting piece of the puzzle is that you can be "wrong" about what emotion you're feeling because many feelings share similar sensations. e.g. confusing fear responses with attraction to somebody because both raise your heart rate. (https://t.co/1j1FB7XhkL).

71. Roughly there are two big characteristics of feelings: Valence and arousal. Valence can be positive (pleasant) or negative (unpleasant), and arousal can be high (agitated) or low (calm). Feelings with similar affect and valence can require some care distinguish.

72. Properly, these are terms used to describe "affect" (https://t.co/zJTwvAbPAQ) - your background state of feelings at a given time. Also I've just discovered that there's a third dimension, motivational intensity (drive to act). Seems plausible, need to think about it.

73. I am not quite sure what the relationship and interplay between the concepts of affect and existential feelings are. I don't think they're the same thing, but I think they describe similar things. Possibly my confusion is because I don't yet understand existential feelings.

74. One key difference is perhaps how bodily the experience is. Understanding your affect is mostly a question of interoception (bodily awareness - https://t.co/ol2CyUrT1u) but understanding existential feelings requires introspection (awareness of your own thoughts).

75. I'm not sure how sharp the line between introspection and interoception is. There are tasks that are mostly introspection (e.g. metacognition, examining your own reasoning) and tasks that are mostly interoception (e.g. noticing an itch) but for feelings you mostly need both.

76. Both are fairly active processes, and there is almost certainly a hard unified skill set around interoception and introspection that people can better at. Developing that skill is probably going to be hugely valuable for most people.

77. I'm still working on those skills, but I think one of the most helpful things to develop them is talking to other people about feelings. An important feature of this is to do both sides of it - take turns explaining your feelings and helping the other understand theirs.

78. This works partly because:

* articulating something is a great way to understand it
* the presence of another person helps overcome aversions
* practising the skill of analysis on someone else is easier because you've got a little more distance

(among other reasons)

79. Apropos nothing, one useful emotional skill is noticing what emotional associations particular things have acquired. A particularly useful term for this is "ugh field" - when things acquire an aura that makes you go "ugh" when you even think about them, so you avoid them.

80. Side note: "emotional" as an adjective doesn't really fit that well into the emotions/feeling split. I think this can be squared by reading "emotional" as meaning "having aspects that it is useful to describe with emotions", but often emotional things are more about feelings.

81. On the earlier point about restricted emotional range: I think one of the benefits of having a rich emotional vocabulary is that it helps you identify when this is happening. It's much easier to notice what your range is if you have words for various points on it.

82. On the earlier point about emotional intensity: I just did a quick google to see if there were any good tips on increasing it. I got pages of advice on how to have *less* intense emotions. I understand why this is but am still vaguely upset by it.

83. Oh, weirdly, the Marie Kondo method is actually quite good as an emotional skill to practice - even if you don't use it to throw things away, taking a specific object and asking how you feel about it (whether it sparks joy) is a well-defined task that you can work on.

84. This ties in to what I was saying earlier about emotions and reasoning: Understanding how you feel about things is an important part of most actions and decision making, so having concrete ways of engaging that helps you get a better handle on your feelings.

85. Another feelings/reason link: Intuition is the application of feelings to reasoning, and intuition is key to good reasoning. One of the biggest differences between a mathematician and a theorem prover is that the mathematician has feelings, so can prioritise what feels right.

86. One reason to get better at int{erocep}{rospec}tion is that sensing is very much an active part of the process of feeling. Regardless of how constructed emotions are, what you do influences how you feel, and examining your emotional state is part of what you do.

87. "Focusing" has the notion of a "body shift", where the felt sense of something changes. This seems to be common to the experience of big emotional realisations for me - when you understand what's going on and suddenly feel a sense of some aspect of yourself coming unstuck.

88. I have an ongoing theory that I have not been able to make work for me (which is not necessarily evidence against it) that poetry is an effective tool for exploring your emotions. Writing it down like that makes it sound very "well, duh", yet we mostly don't do it.

89. Indeed, we think of using poetry to explore your emotional state as childish - a thing done by angsty teens. Actually we label *most* strong expressions of emotions as childish. Perhaps because childhood is the last time we weren't constantly suppressing our emotions?

90. I think this is also why poetry is not that widely appreciated in modern society, and this is where I have difficulty with it too - experiencing poetry properly requires actively engaging with it on an emotional level in a way that I think most people don't know how to do.

91. My suspicion is that writing poetry is actually easier to fix than reading it, and that people should write more angsty poetry, with no intention of sharing it with others. Reading is the key to good writing generally, but the goal here is not to produce good poetry.

92. I've had some fairly profound body shift moments through writing what was... well it wasn't exactly poetry, but it wasn't exactly not poetry either. You can get quite far in that direction with stream of consciousness plus rhythm.

93. I think the childishness thing points to a big problem that I hadn't really verbalised before this thread actually: There's a strong cultural notion that having emotions is childish and/or shameful (and, for men, also shameful because emotions are treated as feminine).

94. This is another feedback loop that makes it hard to figure out your emotions: When you experience emotions - even good ones - strongly, this is experienced as shameful, so you are essentially conditioned away from noticing your emotions.

95. For me at least this was especially reinforced by bullying in childhood - bullies *love* getting you to express strong emotions and then shaming you for that - so that link was set up strongly and at quite a young age.

96. In general we have a huge cultural blindspot to just how much long term emotional damage bullying causes, tied into the childishness/shame issue - adults are expected to be over having spent most of their childhood under constant assault and are seen as weak if they're not.

97. One partial antidote I've found to the shame of exploring your emotions is interest. Treating my emotional state as a neat puzzle to solve seems to provide a useful counterbalance to reluctance to do so. It's not a perfect solution but it helps.

98. I guess it's getting to time to wrap up this thread, so some closing remarks: I don't really know what to do about any of this. It feels like there's a giant poorly understood skill set around emotions that we're barely scratching the surface of and don't know how to teach.

99. I know a lot of people's answer to learning those skills is "Go to therapy!" and for many people that's a great idea, but it's a lot of work to find a good therapist, a lot of money, and when you get there you find they mostly don't know how to teach you these skills anyway.

100. I'm going to continue working on this with friends, partners, and oh so many books. I've no idea how that will go, but it feels like the healthy and responsible thing for me to do. I sure wish we knew what we were doing and someone could just give me the cheat sheet though.
